Great for faster construction and food production. Useful mostly as governor in star systems.
Great for science, dust, luxury and strategic resources production. Useful mostly as governor in star systems.
Experienced in leading fleets into battle. Especially good with strategy. Useful mostly as admiral in fleets.
Great for heroic fighting in space or on the ground. Can make space maneuvers like no other. Useful mostly as admiral in fleets.
Talented for spying, killing, sneaking and, of course, stealing.
This is the current level of the Hero
This is the Hero's salary per turn in Dust
This is the Hero's experience points.

Attributes are bonus factors that will be applied only when the Hero is assigned accordingly (to a system or a fleet). A Hero working in a star system will give his production bonuses to the system, but not his battle bonuses to fleets battling in orbit.
List of the chosen abilities for this hero
List of the unlocked and available abilities for this hero
List of the abilities effects on the hero
This indicates a hero's capacity for producing Food and Industry.
This shows a Hero's skill with Dust and Science.
This indicates how effective a hero is at ground combat (Invasion).
This shows how effective a Hero is when attacking.
This shows how effective a Hero is when defending.
Initial experiences with your empire give the Hero a bonus in every attribute.
Gaining further skills increases all the Hero's attributes.
A seasoned leader, the Hero improves their attributes across the board.
After many trials, the Hero has greatly increased their basic attributes.
In order to improve certain necessary skills, the Hero uses cybernetic augmentation to increase their ability points.
A capable if inexperienced manager, the Hero improves Industry and Food.
With more experience under their belt, the Hero increases output of Industry and Food.
A highly skilled manager of sentients and processes, the Hero gives additional increases to Industry and Food.
Initial practice in their new environment gives the Hero improvements in generating Dust and Science.
A canny moderator and organizer, the Hero grows Dust and Science output.
Among the most efficient governors in the galaxy, the Hero creates another jump in Dust and Science.
Rapidly learning the military systems of your empire, the Hero becomes a dangerous offensive strategist.
Assimilating lessons from defeated enemies and experienced allies, the Hero brings further efficiency to their attack plans.
Now one of the leading offensive leaders in the galaxy, the Hero further improves their attack strategies.
By bringing their knowledge to the existing defensive plans of the empire, the Hero improves defensive bonuses.
With experience comes wisdom; the Hero's skills bring additional strength to your defenses.
Turning every situation to their own advantage, the Hero has become a legend in defense.
Unafraid to get their hands -- or other manipulating extremities -- dirty, the Hero brings a bonus to Melee warfare.
A proven leader of mixed troops in difficult situations, the Hero brings further improvements to Melee tactics.
Gaining galaxy-wide fame for their ability to take ground and never give it up, the Hero is a legend at Melee warfare.
The Hero can take it as well as dish it out; augmentations and implants reduce their need for normal healing.
Not wanting to miss any of the action, the Hero further augments their body to minimize time needed to heal.
A grim, cold foe, this Hero targets enemy commanders without fear for themselves.
Specializing in attacks that disable enemy command structures, the Hero relentlessly removes enemy pieces from the great chess game of warfare.
It is not an easy thing to master Dust, and to go even further into symbiosis with it offers rewards as great as its risks.
Unquestionably altered, and unafraid of perhaps becoming a new species, the Hero further improves their mastery over Dust.
Combining great vision and clear-headed project management, the Hero becomes capable of rapidly realizing vast projects.
Leading teams that study of life sciences and phytology, the Hero greatly improves Food output.
Building on acquired knowledge, Endless technologies, and practical testing, teams led by the Hero further improve Food output.
Understanding the media, the message, and the masses, the Hero is seen as a capable and respected leader.
Manipulating public opinion may seem unethical, but to continue the expansion of an empire the Hero will do it -- and do it quite effectively.
Using a combination of encouragement, new processes, and public information campaigns, the Hero manages to improve overall production of Food.
By organizing education and training to ensure that strategic industries find the resources they need, the Hero manages to improve Industry.
Wishing to encourage the empire in its development, the Hero takes time at every new system to share their expertise and experience.
Planning ahead and developing 'what-if' scenarios, the Hero prepares the planet in advance for the challenges of an alien invasion.
Refining and improving defensive planning, the Hero makes the planets of the system increasingly easy to defend and difficult to conquer.
You can call it making due, cutting corners, or getting the job done. But whatever it takes, the Hero will ensure that even a system under blockade will be able to feed its population.
Interstellar trade is a complex business; as the Hero begins to master its intricacies a system's revenues start to increase.
Clever marketing, efficient logistics, and numerous backroom deals further improve the benefit that a system reaps from its trade routes.
By collaborating and competing in carefully chosen markets, the Hero manages to create additional income from the existing trade routes.
Taking pages from every chapter of the business book -- marketing, negotiations, finance, and technology -- the Hero improves income from Trade routes.
Using a plethora of sophisticated techniques including royalties, trademarks, transmutation, time-shifted purchasing, and self-healing contracts, the Hero ekes additional gains out of Trade routes.
Engaging in aggressive tactics -- cartels, protectionism, takeovers, etc. -- the Hero finds new ways to wring the theoretical maximum out of Trade routes.
Tweaking existing materials and investing in cutting-edge improvements, the Hero manages to make notable gains on the effective distance of detection systems.
Realizing the importance of keeping expensive systems running efficiently, the Hero maintains not only their own infrastructure but also supports fleets in their system.
Developing a technical symbiosis between planetary infrastructure and orbiting fleets, the Hero has set up a win-win environment where fleets can be berthed at zero cost.
The Hero, a sort of financial genius, is capable of unlocking previously hidden value within the science and industry of a system to create new Trade routes.
Taking advantage of sources of wealth -- regardless of where they may be hidden -- is a specialty of the Hero; the creation of value and wealth results in an additional Trade route.
Insights gained through the use of Dust can take many forms. In this case, it is the creation of environments where research and industrial development support each other in a virtuous circle.

An annoying name for an effective practice, the Hero has managed to get all those competing departments and researchers to work in parallel where it is practical, and engage in friendly competition where it is non-destructive.
Trimming costs, hoarding cash, and carefully tracking expenditures may not be glamorous, but it certainly creates results.
A combination of carefully planned battles, sophisticated maneuvers, and years of experience, the Hero shows an uncanny ability to evade incoming enemy fire.
Beyond military brilliance is the ability of the Hero to interface intimately with battle systems through the use of Dust; they show a capacity to force enemy systems to miss their targets.
The Hero is one of those who is driven by competition to exceed above and beyond their already elevated skill level; when in battle with an equal foe their talents truly shine.
By combining careful propaganda with a strict policy of avoiding civilian casualties, the Hero is able to rapidly convince defending populations to support his empire.
Unafraid to lead from the front and inspire their troops, this exemplary Hero gains bonuses on both Offense and Defense.
By creating a healthy team environment of cooperation, outsiders and attempted intrusions are quickly identified and their plans quickly nullified.
Tireless and intense, the Hero moves at an aggressive pace. They will always go to where they are needed most, eagerly accepting new challenges.
• +25% critical chance on player's kinetics (block: +15%) • +25% critical chance on player's missiles (block: +15%)
• +25% deflection on player's deflectors (block: +15%) • +25% interception on player's antimissiles (block: +15%) • +25% absorption on player's shields (block: +15%)
• Destroyed ships during this phase will be considered as still alive after the end of the battle, with 5% of their max HP restored
Often disliked by their troops for their intensity and drive, the ability of the Hero to analyze situations and learn from every victory and defeat is nevertheless greatly appreciated.
Additional experience and a Dust-enhanced capacity to learn and re-deploy in real time allows the Hero's fleet to gain experience at a rapid pace.
A mechanic at heart, the Hero's capacity to analyze and improve the already advanced engines of their fleet permits their ships to move farther and faster.
Gleaning engine tuning lessons from other empires and Endless remains, major overhauls are done to the drive systems that greatly increase the distance of travel.
By tuning and tweaking weapon and shield systems, the Hero manages to eke out improvements in both Offense and Defense.
More than simple adjustments and refinements, the Hero has led weapon system overhauls that provide great bonuses in Offence and Defense.
By tuning the entirety of the weapon system, from projectile to targeting to delivery, the Hero gives a major offensive boost to their fleet.
Relying on extensive experience in brutal wars of attrition in the Arcturus sector, the Hero has perhaps the highest level of expertise in Defense in the galaxy.
Taking personal pride in the resiliency and recovery speed of their fleet, the Hero executes post-engagement repairs at an accelerated pace.
Relying on friendly shipyards and supplies, the advanced maintenance processes implemented by the Hero greatly speed up recovery time for damaged ships.
With a natural ability to adapt to changing and hostile conditions, the Hero is able to repair and regenerate even when outside friendly territory.
A combination of preset navigation systems and engines that can mount to full power without movement, the Hero can make immediate jumps towards friendly territory before their fleet can be targeted.
• +25% of max HP added to armor (block: +15%)
• +300% efficiency to next phase’s battle action
• -15% damage on enemy's weapons (block: -10%) • +15% damage on player's weapons (block: +10%)
Making the most out of the enemy's failure, the Hero collects additional Dust per Command Point for the battles that they win -- regardless of which side lost those CPs.
Always thinking ahead, looking ahead, and gathering data from eclectic sources, the Hero is aware of any vessels approaching a fleet or system much earlier than usual.
Acting under cover for the hiring faction, the Hero carefully collects a small amount of Dust per level from the enemy or ally system where they are located.
Improving their attunement to Dust and their ability to collect it, the Hero increases the amount of Dust unofficially obtained from the enemy or ally system where they are located.
A student of surveillance and detection systems, the Hero allows their fleet to 'piggyback' on the detection systems of enemy systems they are orbiting.
Making the most out of the enemy's failure, the Hero collects additional Dust per Command Point for the battles that they win -- regardless of which side lost those CPs.
Clever, canny, and hard as Adamantian nails, when the Hero is a system Governor their ability to get supplies and support means that the effects of an enemy Blockade are nullified.

Realizing that empires require data and technology, unafraid of being on the cutting edge of risk and reward, the Hero siphons a certain amount of Science from enemy and ally systems in which they are located.
Working surreptitiously, the Hero improves their ability to steal Science points from enemy or ally systems where they are stationed.

The Hero has the advantage of additional information on an enemy's strengths and weaknesses. Exploiting this to their advantage during invasions, the Hero is good at hitting the enemy where it hurts the most.
• +20% damage on player's lasers (block: +10%) • -20% deflection on enemy's deflectors (block: -10%)
• Creates illusions based on 40% of fleet CP (block: +10%)

Famous for her objective analysis of fact and data, she has been known to measure ingredients to the microgram when cooking for pleasure. Her area of specialty is complex systems and n-dimensional equations. Friendly as a general rule, but too precise to be 'warm,' $Last has a temper and has studied enough martial arts to be effective when she loses it.

Even among a people who pride themselves as thinkers and analyzers, $Last stands out. Initially fascinated by materials science and physical chemistry, this interest evolved to include nanomaterials and quantum devices when he became infected by Dust. Now a research team leader, $Last's abilities in problem-solving are greatly sought after for development and planning.

$Last is considered a fluke by its Sower counterparts; though an efficient co-worker it is unusually adapted to and eager for combat. The reproduction process that creates Sowers is strict and the quality high, but even in this case quantum fluctuations can have surprising results.

Nicknamed "Mastermind" due to its dust-enhanced abilities, $Last became famous for organizing the building of a railroad through quicksand during a hurricane with only scrap metal and vines as raw materials. It was completed ahead of schedule.

A ranking leader in the Swarm, at the Bishop level and therefore capable of independent thought. Infiltration of Dust led it to reject hive life and begin to study humanitarian philosophy, existentialism, determinism... Was driven from hive, found a berth on a trader and ended up in faction jail as a dangerous life form.

As a flight officer, $Last's meteoric rise through the Horatio faithful and their political success showed an innate knack for intrigue, and left them poised to influence the future of the Horatio empire. Sadly, their acute narcissism surfaced and fostered a deep rooted conviction that theirs was the natural evolution of the Horatio DNA strain. Immediate reassignment to a remote outpost showed that Horatio Prime did not concur.

When a nanoplague almost wiped out his homeworld, Prime, through a combination of acumen, luck and research, managed to keep remnants of civilization alive long enough for help to arrive. Since then he is a valued troubleshooter for the Cravers. More contemplative than the rest of his race, he is a creative thinker who enjoys strategic planning and carefully husbands his resources. Ultimately he has the same urges as the rest of his race, but keeps them better in check. Many of his race despise him for his lack of ravenous appetite but he is too useful to simply kill outright.

$Last is viewed as a useful man to have around. A hard worker, he is good with his hands, even when they are carrying weapons. Though his Dust-augmented skills greatly improved his ability to tinker with the technical infrastructure of Pilgrims ships, he is more than happy to jump to their defense when they are threatened.

A planner and thinker, this Horatio is respected for her diligence as well for her capabilities in battle. Due to the fact that she was a child of a promising batch whose resemblance to the original Horatio was better than average, she was not destroyed as aberrant when she showed these unusual skills in combat.

More than most modern warriors, the analysis and exploitation of data is key to this Hissho's battlefield decisions. Foregoing instinct and intuition, decisions are taken based on history, trends, and probabilities. While her victories tend to be less flamboyant and fewer songs are sung, she is appreciated among the rank and file for bringing them home victorious -- and alive.

Enjoyed exploring and discovering other factions; was generally less worried than other Clones about constant human contact. Experience with Dust gave her a sense of the individual, of the perspective of the universe. She went mad. She is currently being treated by faction doctors.

Adapt or die is not merely a biological rule, it is equally true of technology. $Last understood this early, and continually sought new and better ways to execute its tasks. From more efficient parallelization of tasks to the use of upgraded materials, adapting and changing has been the story of its existence. Once enhanced through Dust, $Last turned her optical receptors to the stars themselves. It now seeks new places, new things, and new ideas that can further improve its ability to adapt.

$Last is an anomaly amongst her fellow Sophon cousins. While her intellectually inclined brethren strive for scientific and technological betterment, $Last was far more interested in studying the ways of war, from the ancient Empire text of San Tzo to the Way of the Hissho. Her natural Sophon thirst for knowledge led her far and wide in her adventures, whilst learning the martial ways of other races.

Led a small team that wrote a paper convincing the United Empire of the economic inefficiency of slavery as a Human Resources policy. Was put on a Wanted list for that effrontery, and subsequently fled and joined the Pilgrims. Intensely committed to the human condition and the dignity of the individual, she has never failed to do what she believes is right.

Like all Amoeba, this one is a seeker and a thinker. Creative, conceptual, and curious, it seeks to find and discover other cultures and see how they can be befriended, exploited, and used. This is not out of cruelty or malice, but a deep-seated need for the Amoeba to be in control of their collective destiny. As result, it is a highly effective commander.

Hissho war leader, captured during a small engagement in contested space. Sole survivor of prison ship encounter with Endless craft; was the only one emotionally stable enough to handle the effects of Dust. Originally from Westline Archipelago on the Hissho homeworld. Quiet, aloof, withdrawn. Smiles rarely, and when he does, nobody is really sure why.

A product of the Empire's Corporate Military Academy, $Last's success as a pilot led her to lucrative sponsorship contracts with corporations that were underwriting colonization efforts. Her dry wit and irreverent attitude undermined were at odds with their PR plans, however, so $Last was left alone--happily--to pursue her dreams of flight and exploration.

An entity that likes to federate and bring beings together, diplomacy and exploration are natural interests for $Last Collaborative work, group cooperation, and overcoming obstacles are the things that make it happy. Keenly sensing its individuality since it ingested Dust, it almost fervent in its desire to explore and unite peoples.

A dangerous operator, $Last is known for his affection for data. He will take the time necessary to analyze and calculate risks, then happily leap in and take them. As a member of a corporate/military security department, $Last volunteered as a guinea pig to be infiltrated by Dust.

Born a Slave that worked its way up to Drone and Forager, it ingested a great deal of Dust while tracking potential energy readings on a sterile moon. Rejecting its hive, it was subsequently picked up by passing Sowers, then sought further knowledge and ended up at the Academy. It never lost, however, the hard-won respect for its prowess in battle as a Flight Drone.

Though she grew up in a strict system of hierarchy and caste, $Last was from an early age a rogue and a rule-breaker. Cleverer than most and skilled in combat, she left home at an early age when the clan's city, then her region, and finally the planet seemed too small for her. Skilled in trade and negotiation and superlative in defense, she has been sought after by traders, corporations, and several police forces.
High ranking Hissho leader, fiercely independent and forever curious. Left home planet to study navigation with Academy. Originally from Northern Wastes on the Hissho homeworld.

Ivan lived his early life among his people, learning the trades of thievery and trickery. He met his destiny the day he tried to steal Dust from a plain-clothed officer of the Empire's Secret Service; the dust he stole from the officer rose to his defense before he could be captured. That same day a special assault squad cornered him in his hideout and they made him an offer he couldn't refuse...

A strategist and warrior for a successful and growing hive, it was a bishop-level leader of war groups. Deciding, logically, that the most efficient way to be able to do more for the hive would be to consume Dust, it did so and was forever changed. Smarter, faster, more aggressive, and tougher, it rapidly outpaced its hive development and became a mercenary, seeking ever-greater challenges.

Led a team of experts in Imaging & Particle Systems from the department of Probe & Live Exploration. A natural leader with a sly sense of humor, she encountered Dust while investigating a Endless temple. Enhanced by its capacities, she decided to enter Academy and learn more of Dust and its uses.

For a number of reasons $Last was known as "Vice President of Winter." His icy blue eyes and his breathy speech pattern were once accompanied by a coldly analytic decision-making process that made even his bosses shiver. It is said that he has recently become secretive and cautious, after what rumor says was a mysterious encounter with a Sheredyn spy on Sophon territory. It is also said that he has now been seen, on occasion, to flash a ghost of a smile.

Smart, subtle, and dangerous, at least three clients have hired $Last so that their enemies could not. Clever, wily, and very efficient on defense, he was key in forcing a stalemate when working for the outnumbered and outgunned Jabhat Colonists' Collective. It was simply a business deal when he left to work for a higher bidder, leaving them teetering on the brink...

While most of the Sower machines have simple interest in the mechanics of the job, $Last was fascinated by what went on behind, beneath, and inside of the cities they built or the ones they discovered. Made curious by Dust and seeking further understanding, $Last has made a profession of studying the materials and mechanics within all cultures.

Quite restless by Amoeba standards, $Last is driven to experience all that can be experienced in this vast cosmos. Early in life, it gained a reputation as loose cannon while working to combat smugglers in the Vestibule of Creation. Later, It took up Leadership of a Hissho mercenary company, employed by rogue Sophon scientists to capture Craver tech. After a long battle with Dust addiction in Its middle years and a stint in an Empire prison, introspection drove It to explore the universe at a more leisurely pace. Time may have tempered this one's rash behavior, but not Its thirst for adventure.

A race of identical beings is often perturbed -- even horrified -- by other peoples who show variety from one individual to another. $Last however, showed fascination and curiosity for alien races rather than repulsion. Once he was touched by Dust, however, his explorations and investigations became ever deeper and wider, as he crossed galaxies at the head of teams who were seeking new planets.

$Last was a very bright, yet very shy child in the beginning. When his parents put him through the Sophon equivalent of college, he demonstrated ironic prowess in an ability: public speaking. His profound abilities coupled with his immense capabilities for management and administration made him a grade A bureaucrat AND a man of the people, making him a great choice for managing a populace.

The surprising thing about $Last was not his brilliance, but that fact that he was also pragmatic and useful in construction and development. The combination of skills made an impression on the Sophon College, who granted him Dust augmentation in order to further spur his efforts.

As dedicated and hard-working as all Sowers, $Last also showed a talent for ground warfare when the Sowers pacified an unruly local populace on a developing planet. Receiving a Dust augmentation to aid her efforts, in three months $Last went from running construction on one continent to managing an entire colonial system.

After a few hundred years of quiet and unremarkable existence, Ap0110 was catapulted to fame when she led a potent counter-attack that threw off a Craver ground assault. After driving them out of a system in a series of brilliant offensive maneuvers, she became highly sought after as a leader.

The only sane survivor from a Craver raiding vessel that cracked open a Endless hulk, $Last's phenomenal skills in construction and development have made it rich. Demand is high for its services, in spite of the occasional PTSD-driven breakdown. $Last has become one of the leading experts in the galaxy on industrial development.

$Last was always a hard worker who took pleasure in creation and construction. After a period of military service, in which he obtained notable marks in ground warfare, a Horatio-ordered Dust enhancement turned him into a effective colonial governor.

A leader of Craver colonizing teams, $Last stumbled over a Dust lode when leading construction on an asteroid belt. Rapidly outgrowing its colleagues and hive, $Last turned to other factions to find challenging projects that could assuage its new-found curiosity.

One of the many Pilgrims leaders who learned hard lessons about building and defending habitats in the Second Separation War, $Last's skills in construction and defense were notable even before they were improved by Dust.

$Last's career began as a methodical developer of biological pacification projects on new worlds. Responsible for converting land into farms and industrial zones, the discovery of a crashed Endless probe infected the entire team with Dust. As the only survivor of the incident, $Last remains a humble, if gifted, worker.

While the Hissho generally prefer air combat, $Last had an instinct for ground warfare. After leading a highly successful attack on a well-entrenched United Empire outpost, $Last was one of twenty Hissho warriors to whom a Dust augmentation was proposed--and the only one who survived.

The Horatio had established a beachhead outpost on an asteroid belt in a system coveted by the Amoeba. $Last, at the time an administrator of a cloning facility, led a successful defense and counter-attack to secure their position. As a result, Horatio granted her a Dust augmentation for service to the Siblings.

The Sowers have a shared consciousness within communication range, and therefore have little need to specialize as individuals. $Last however, was an experimental model who (for reasons understandable only to quantum computing psycho-engineers) turned out to have a great knack for ground warfare.

Sophons are generally called "smart", but $Last is one of the very rare for whom "…and dangerous" is added on. Defending an Endless site from a hungry Craver attack, she showed a striking ability as both strategist and tactician.

$Last learned how to run a colony during the difficult closing months of the Second Separation War. While her skills at ground warfare are respectable, she truly excels in the development of scientific research stations and converting their output into money.

Angered by a minor race of belligerent sentients who preferred assassination to negotiation, $Last showed a flair for military command when it drove them out of three asteroid belts, two planets, and then forced a highly unequal treaty on them. $Last is a living incarnation of the adage that "war is the continuation of diplomacy by other means."

Endowed with high intelligence to match above-average skills in ground warfare, $Last's already rapid career progression leapt ahead when his colonization ship landed on a Visited moon. His dust-augmented capacities drove him to the forefront of Hissho expansion, until his impatience with tradition and hierarchy made him leave in frustration.

$Last's career followed an average arc of success, as she was a capable but unremarkable corporate lieutenant. However, an unprotected exposure to over-excited Dust in a military research facility triggered changes that launched her up the corporate pyramid--until boredom drove her to seek challenges elsewhere.

$Last was never one for fighting, always going on about science this, testing that. It was only when the Amoeban government tried to shut down her tests that she got dangerous, nearly destroying the entire system she was in as she fled with her data. Today she roams the known universe trying to get support for her scientific pursuits from other factions.

Living on that fuzzy line somewhere between "unpredictable" and "out of control", $Last was an erratic if successful leader of colonial explorations. When his mission uncovered an Endless site and $Last was augmented by the free-floating Dust, his eccentricities seemed to get worse. At that point the Empire decided it would be far better for him to find work elsewhere...

Dust exposure before birth/creation gave this Craver a distinct "jack of all trades, master of none" nature; not extremely skilled in any pursuit, yet not unskilled in any. Such a nature also made her more disposed to intellectual pursuit than most Cravers. Due to her multitude of skills she sees the important red thread between the varying institutions of society. She toils endlessly to bolster harmony between them, hoping to further the Craver race as a whole.

There is a war cry among the Hissho that would roughly translate as, "Come at me!" $Last, a fearsome fighter, was known for her use of this challenge and her near-impervious defenses -- as an individual and as a leader of troops. This made her part of an augmentation selection. Though she was one of the 8% that survived, she was not of the remaining 88% that was still good at taking orders...

$Last, who had already become the most famous warrior in his clan's history, earned the nickname "Either Way" during a war against a league of pirates. When the pirates explained that they had sufficient numbers to obliterate him whether they attacked or defended, he simply shrugged. "Start the battle as you please. Either way, you're dead."

The histories of many large nations are often the histories of great adversaries. $Last, known as the "Unstoppable Force," had a perfect record of victories in both simulations and on the field. Data indicates that he may be the greatest field commander ever known to the empire. Except, of course, the UE Admiral Forsythe.

A Dust-enhanced Craver found drifting in a broken hulk, $Last showed an unusual capacity to work with other species. Its abilities made it very useful in warfare, especially in defense. However it appears to be driving itself to death, consciously or not, in an endless string of increasingly dangerous battles.

"Nobody touches my orbital and gets away with it." A gritty, scarred warrior who stands out in a race of seekers and explorers, $Last uttered these famous words when a United Empire scouting party attempted to forcibly re-integrate $Last's 2,000-person habitat back into the empire. When the Dust finally cleared, the Empire's task force had been defeated, looted, and covered with insulting graffiti.

Born on Earth, $Last was always fascinated with stars, even as a child. He left the planet as soon as he could with the military, where he progressed through the ranks. Young and charismatic, $Last demonstrated an uncanny ability to assess a battlefield quickly and organize effective defenses. Over the course of the several years, his intervention saved many empire ships from destruction. It goes without saying that his skill and determination to minimize losses have made him very popular among the common servicemen.

Three times $Last executed the monumental effort of scouting, proposing, and implementing the establishment of a colony on a new world--while under enemy fire. His ability to stay cool under pressure earned him the nickname "Iceberg."

Thrust into development of a system inhabited by a hostile species, $Last was one of a subgroup of Sowers who ended up developing advanced skills in ground warfare. As the only member of her vessel to survive impact with an Endless ship fragment, she is now a freelance expert in this grim field.

"Warrior Amoeba" is, without surprise, viewed as an impossible oxymoron. Yet $Last, driven almost to madness as he watched his fleet get destroyed by the guns of an ancient Endless defense satellites, vowed to never again avoid -- or lose -- a battle.

DNA manipulation is a complex science, and even masters of cloning like the Horatio occasionally get unexpected results -- like $Last. Intended to have the skills of an excellent construction foreman, he in fact became a talented military leader.

Skuoi Kyryi was part of a small community that had created a large, complex infrastructure across a series of large asteroids. They learned of the Great Schism and the Dust Wars when an unmanned probe scattered hostile Dust across their habitat, dissolving the gangways and corridors. As the contents of the community were forcibly jettisoned into the vacuum of space, Skuoi, who had been outside repairing antennae and computer infrastructures, watched friends and family die.
Leading a small band of survivors he managed to isolate and counter-act the Dust invasion, though too late to save enough of the community to keep it viable. When the emergency mission that took them away finally reached a safe base, Skuoi was the only one who had not died of thirst.
A pitiless warrior and relentless adversary, the rage that burned within Skuoi did not die for decades. He became one of the most feared members of the Concrete defenses, though after numerous assassination attempts his body was eventually almost completely remade as an android.
Finally burned out and desiring peace and silence, rather than war and vengeance, Skuoi set himself adrift across the cosmos in cold stasis, living on memories. It is there that he was discovered; with his cause and his peoples long dead or gone, Skuoi is content to use his skills in the service of worthwhile allies.

Skuoi Kyryi was part of a small community that had created a large, complex infrastructure across a series of large asteroids. They learned of the Great Schism and the Dust Wars when an unmanned probe scattered hostile Dust across their habitat, dissolving the gangways and corridors. As the contents of the community were forcibly jettisoned into the vacuum of space, Skuoi, who had been outside repairing antennae and computer infrastructures, watched friends and family die.
Leading a small band of survivors he managed to isolate and counter-act the Dust invasion, though too late to save enough of the community to keep it viable. When the emergency mission that took them away finally reached a safe base, Skuoi was the only one who had not died of thirst.
A pitiless warrior and relentless adversary, the rage that burned within Skuoi did not die for decades. He became one of the most feared members of the Concrete defenses, though after numerous assassination attempts his body was eventually almost completely remade as an android.
Finally burned out and desiring peace and silence, rather than war and vengeance, Skuoi set himself adrift across the cosmos in cold stasis, living on memories. It is there that he was discovered; with his cause and his peoples long dead or gone, Skuoi is content to use his skills in the service of worthwhile allies.

The Automatons take their role as caretakers so seriously, that certain horticulturalists gave their wards the capacity for self defense. Tan-Erbo went the farthest, developing a race of carnivorous and partially mobile giant orange plants that were set free to act as guardians of certain zones. However, the Automaton was unaware that these plants would assault anything foreign -- including Automatons. It was attacked during a routine inspection, and though it escaped the plants did manage to rip its head off. Fortunately, this did not result in decommission as its neural system had a wireless back-up. Tan-Erbo now travels with its head removed from its body, a solemn reminder of the risks of playing at god.

Granddaughter of the famous Deona Kryv, the Pilgrim visionary who launched the first Fleet Errant, Jana lived forever in the shadow of her more famous predecessor. This happened in spite of the fact that she was a genius and prodigy in xenotechnology and astrogation, receiving advanced doctorates in three related sciences by the age of 27. Driven to ever greater extremes and more amazing feats in order to make her own name famous, Jana disappeared into an unmapped stellar cluster after decoding an Endless navigational beacon. Lost and assumed dead, it was only when a strange quantum-tunneled signal emerged from that same cluster that the rest of the galaxy realized something was happening. Jana herself emerged shortly thereafter, somewhat dazed by the experience and rather surprised at what she had triggered.

Rach was part of a pirate team that discovered an Endless research station -- on a supposedly empty asteroid -- whose systems had been awakened by Kryv's signal. Unfortunately the station's signature was picked up by a Sheredyn fleet that immediately moved in and took out Rach's ship. She hid in the Dust-infested station until an Amoeba mission picked her up; a fortunate event as the Amoebas tend to try pirates before executing them. Impressed by her intelligence and reason, Rach was freed and now sells her services across the galaxy.

Only known as Tephys, this hero was trained as an interrogator for the Sheredyn Military Police. An orphan and loner, for her the Sheredyn was the only sure thing in an untrustworthy universe. However, with the ascent of Emperor Zelevas and the sudden independence of the Sheredyn, Tephys's world destabilized. Turning assassin and infiltrator, she was captured by an unknown entity while trying to kidnap a Sophon scientist specializing in Endless technologies. Whatever happened that day, it caused her to leave the Sheredyn command structure and continue as an independent.

Going by the name of his calling rather than his totally unpronounceable family name, Techseeker is part of a race of intelligent amphibian omnivores (Plocynos) inhabiting a swamp world, Codylus III. Driven by a fascination with mechanics and systems from a young age, contacts with space-faring species led Techseeker into an unexpected contact with an Endless artifact that crumbled to Dust as he inspected it. Surviving this exposure, he reveled in the power and insight that his Dust-enhanced powers gave him. Now a restless researcher of technology and industry, it should also be noted that he is very useful to have around during bar fights.

This hero of an unknown race was found in a gutted ship, drifting in orbit around an unexplored planet. With the ship apparently destroyed by an ancient defensive ring of Dust mines that had been reanimated by Kryv's act, only Bor -- who has yet to remove his or her suit, for unknown reasons -- survived. While generally silent and dour, slow to speak and quite serious, Bor seems lively and more energetic in groups, gaining energy from others.

$Last was best known for squeezing every last bit of value out of his operations -- and his employees. Generally hated for his management style if respected for his wealth, over a 24-hour period $Last underwent a stunning, 180-degree personality change. Rumors based on hearsay refer to Dust-induced hallucinations pertaining to historical occurrences, present day operations, and probability distributions of future events. Regardless of the reason, $Last left his job as head of accounting at the Polaris Workshop and now travels the galaxy, still famed for his management but also for his generosity.

An Automaton pilot, Ora-Yur was damaged by an artifical gravity machine during a scientific mission. Reduced to the level of a barely self-aware machine tool, it was posessed by a Virtual Endless and turned into an Automaton superman. When the Endless retreated back to its own android body, the power to manipulate Dust remained.

Appointed as the operator of an industrial platform orbiting a gas giant during the Dust Wars, Neuil's skills at production were greatly appreciated until the war moved elsewhere, and he was left alone. After spending milennia maintaining the platform, he was found and expatriated by an Automaton scientific expedition. Neuil now roams the galaxy, putting his many years of practical knowledge in industry and warfare to work for his clients.

A highly decorated commander in the UEH navy, Carter quit the service in 3536 when she could no longer ignore the Empire's acts of atrocity against Amoeba civilians. Now a pirate and freelance troublemaker, she is extremely wealthy and a constant source of trouble for the UEH. Though she seems to be in it for the money, in fact Carter harbors notions of building a fleet strong enough to give the Empire what it deserves. If she does not live long enough to do it, she will pass the task on to her unborn child.

As beings that evolved on a Dust-rich gas giant, the culture and society of the Deuyivan are either incomprehensible or inexplicable. Therefore, to simplify communication they tend to adopt the names of other sentients that they meet. Neuil, a mathematical genius who applied his skills to financial models and game theory, took the name of an Endless leader that he met during his first trip off his home planet.

You are at war with this empire, and free to attack him anywhere.
You are at peace with this empire, which prevents you from attacking each other.
You share a Cold War status with this empire. Your territories cannot be attacked directly, but skirmishes are possible in star systems not owned by either of you.
You are in an alliance with this empire, sharing all decisions to declare peace and war on other empires. You can see each others' systems and travel freely within them.
This will notify the contacted empire that you declare war on them. No answer is needed
This will request the contacted empire to make peace with you. If they agree, you will have access to more advanced diplomatic options.

This term stops the ongoing war. During a definite number of turns, both opponents are placed in a state of cold war and may not declare war neither ask peace. At the end of this waiting, a peace treaty will be proposed.

This term stops the ongoing war. During a definite number of turns, both opponents are placed in a state of cold war and may not declare war neither ask peace. At the end of this waiting, a peace treaty will be proposed.
After an initial cost (necessary to set up the trade agreements), both empires will benefit from a substantial increase in revenue from trade routes.
This will allow the empire to navigate freely in your territories (requires Peace).
This will propose to the contacted empire that you form an alliance together.
This will offer the contacted empire to join your alliance
This will cause you to leave your current alliance. No answer is needed.

The specified quantity of Dust is transferred every turn, until the deal is cancelled.

RESPONSES TO REQUEST TO THE ALLIANCE
$Name is uncertain about this alliance request.
The answer given by the other empire.
Though your recent actions are of some concern, we feel obligated to try to restore harmony to our worlds.
War is such a difficult way to find solutions to common problems. Are you willing to discuss alternatives?
When improvements occur between entities that are engaged in hostilities, one always hopes that peace and harmony might win out.
Ah, to be in such an agreement with a trusted nation of like-minded souls! Sadly that is not the case, but we would try to make it so.
A proposal of cooperation is always welcome in a dangerous galaxy, is it not? Please give this proper consideration.
It is unfortunate that not all leaders share your openness and wisdom. Would greater co-operation be possible?
In spite of your tendency to rash and unharmonious behavior, we feel the galaxy would benefit from a closer relationship.
We of the Amoeba understand the opportunities and complexities of alliances. Would you be prepared to face such challenges with us?
Please understand that this type of proposal is not made lightly! In your behavior we see hopes for true galactic unity.
With heavy hearts, we notify you that your actions have forced this situation upon us. Would that it were not so!
War means death, waste, pollution, and a loss of harmony and unity. Though the Amoeba abhor it, we fear it is necessary.
Is this the only solution to our current situation? The Amoeba hope for something a bit more positive, but see no other course of action.
Though some minds counsel that this seems to be against our interests, we nevertheless invite you to join with us.
Have you noted the existence of our joyous federation of friends? We were wondering if you are fated to become part of it.
It is hard work, to maintain such a union of like-minded souls. We ask you to share the burden of its continued success.
There is some discomfort with your place within this alliance. Perhaps we should have reflect upon our mutual concerns earlier.
In many relationships, the time comes when one must accept the possibility of failure, even in an association as fruitful as ours.
Our humble request may be unexpected, but there remains some dissatisfaction with your role in our alliance.
Ah, peace! Such a worthy goal; such an important step to greater things. And, in spite of your activities, we extend it as an offer.
As things stand, the creation of a lasting peace between us is certainly worth consideration. Peace is, after all, a harbinger of greater things.
The Amoeba cherish the ideals of peace and harmony most deeply; we can only hope that improving relations convince you of the same.
While our hopes lead us to desiring this opportunity, recent decisions on your part indicate that you may not feel the same.
This concept appeals to our love of integration and harmony, though reserve must be taken that we do not expose ourselves unduly.
To freely mix and mingle, sharing wisdom and ideas, communing across the bounds of space and culture… Does this also appeal to your worthy citizens?
Often, when proposals are made without an existing understanding, their goal is purely avaricious. We assure you that is not our situation, regardless of your impunity.
Trade is not, in and of itself, an end; it is but a means to a deeper understanding between cultures. Are you prepared to join us in this?
As relations between us improve, every little act -- even if it is purely economic -- can only be seen as a step towards a greater communion. Do you agree?
Good will should be improving, not declining, for the Automaton to trust others. However, redemption is possible.
The Automaton ask whether such a step is possible in the light of current situations.
The Automaton sees no risk to its duties from this proposal; do others feel the same?
To co-operate with the Automaton, one should show less scorn for the Automaton. Here is a chance.
Of the many things that could realistically happen, is this one desirable? Much good can come of mutual efforts.
Indications are that co-operation could benefit the Automaton as well as other entities.
The Automaton sees difficulty in an alliance where there is no trust or empathy. But to try is concordant with our duties.
This puts the Automaton's fate in others' hands. It must be considered carefully.
The Automaton seldom sees value in this situation. Yet with trustworthy entities it is generally aids our duties.
The Automaton is not surprised that others' actions have driven us to this deplorable state. The Automaton will not concede.
The Automaton is not defenseless, nor inactive. Threats to our duty and efforts cannot be tolerated.
The Automaton apologizes. Relations appear to trend positively, yet conflict is inevitable.
The Automaton offers this with reservation, as there is a situation of declining trust.
The Automaton values autonomy, as do other entities. However, this proposal has merits.
The Automaton sees value in mutual efforts with trusted entities.
The Automaton is used to being alone and independent. Others' actions require that we reinstate this condition.
The Automaton understands that sometimes things occur. This is simply a thing.
The Automaton realizes that this proposal was not expected, given current trends in relationships.
The Automaton seldom makes peace with entities who cannot be trusted. This is an exception.
Fixing a peace agreement is not a simple matter. The Automaton deliberated long before making this offer.
Peace is preferable to war. Creation is greater than destruction. Trends indicate that other entities agree.
The Automaton borders usually remain closed to those who cannot be trusted. Yet we offer, in spite of the risk.
The proposal could cause vulnerabilities. The Automaton has discussed it, and feels it is nevertheless appropriate.
The Automaton usually closes its borders. But this proposal is for a trusted entity, and the Automaton sees little risk.
The Automaton will not become reliant on unreliable entities, so this proposal is unusual.
The Automaton sees benefit in mutual enrichment.
The Automaton does not see unexpected risk in this proposal, given positive trends in others' actions.
You have one chance. This is it.
It serves the hive. Accept, or the hive serves you.
For cannon fodder, you are not without merit.
Cooperate. This is not necessarily an offer.
The hive seldom cooperates with its food. This is an exception.
This is a rare offer. The hive views you as more than just a source of nutrition.
Though your death is preferable, an alliance is possible.
We extend the offer to eat, uh, *rule* your citizens.
The hive rarely makes alliances, but is willing to make this exception.
The hive looks forward to this.
Though you are offensive, an alliance may be useful.
This is an offer that seems reasonable. Not wonderful.
It is rare for the hive to view others as anything but a light snack.
No, this is not a polite request.
An alliance no longer appears to be of value to the hive.
It is unfortunate. It is also necessary. Goodbye.
It hurts us to do this, but we offer you peace.
Take it or leave it. We are indifferent.
We are surprised that we are doing this.
You are unpleasant, but the offer is genuine.
Please open your borders to our fleets. Did we phrase that badly?
The hive sees many advantages to this. Which is unusual.
The hive is forced to stoop to petty commerce.
Exchange for mutual benefit. What a strange concept.
Given your trustworthiness, the hive is prepared to trade.
Though there is no glory in 'Cease Fire', it is offered in spite of your temerity.
To the Hissho, it is better to fire than to cease. But still, the offer is made.
It is possible, if not preferable, to cease hostilities with a worthy foe.
Co-operation is for friends and allies. You appear to be neither, but the offer is made.
Co-operation could be to both of our benefit. This is not a question of honor, but pragmatism.
This will not bring glory, but perhaps some profit. Does your emperor find that interesting?
There is seldom good reason to ally with those who lack honor. However, conditions require the Hissho offer this.
The greater the force, the greater the potential victory. Is your emperor prepared to join us?
Together, we can create such a history that the stars will sing our praises. Let us celebrate this day!
All actions have consequences. In this case, yours may cause the end of you.
War is not an evil thing; it is a way we may measure our greatness.
This offer of honorable conflict may be unexpected. But with an honorable enemy, it is welcome.
It is difficult to enter into an alliance with those who are viewed with contempt. However, in this case it is necessary.
The thought of a more powerful union is appealing, no? The greater the force, the greater the enemies, the greater the glory to be had.
An interesting challenge, no? Together we can find greater conquests to bring glory to this great alliance.
There is no shame for you to leave this alliance. And for us, honor demands you depart.
What is today is an amicable separation may tomorrow be war. Let us hope that this is so.
The hopes for greater honor have not yet waned; the Hissho prefer to continue their battles without you.
Our citizens are angry that we offer peace to you; they would prefer your deaths. Think carefully on this offer.
Peace cannot come without trust, and never at the price of honor. The Hissho are prepared to offer it.
An honorable end to a righteous struggle will not bring disgrace to our people.
The opening of our borders is an embarrassment, given your behavior. We hope the results justify it.
A decision this important required a sacrifice and much discussion. The Hissho honor you by offering it.
The Hissho see worthy allies in your people; we hope better relations confirm this.
Though your people do not seem worthy of it, we make this offer to you.
There are practical reasons to trade, when greater glory is not possible.
Your integrity indicate an honorable people; our proposal salutes this.
Horatio does not like you, but we would like the noise to stop.
Shall we cease hostilities? Or maybe have some tea. Decisions, decisions…
Strange. A cease fire with you almost feels like a good idea.
We offer this treaty of co-operation, though it is painful to do so with such louts.
I suppose we could co-operate. A bit. On some things. What do you think?
There's so many things we could co-operate on. Wine, fashion, jewelry, perfumes…
The thought of you sniffing around our planets makes us vaguely queasy. But I suppose it might be worthwhile.
We could ally. Not a great idea, not an awful idea. It just sort of came to us. What do you think?
We are prepared to honor you with an alliance. Try not to scream for joy, our ears are sensitive.
Don't think of it as war. Think of it as divine punishment for your lack of refinement.
It's not that you're particularly brutish toads. It's just that war seems like a good idea.
Isn't that sweet? We don't just declare war on anybody. They have to be really special.
If my advisors weren't so pushy, there is no way I'd offer an alliance to anyone as tacky as you are.
Well, I suppose it's not a bad idea to form an alliance. And it gives me a good reason to order people around some more.
Oh, my. Who wouldn't want an alliance with people as charming as you are. A bit of the bubbly to celebrate?
Out, out, out. You're beginning to stink up the place.
Don't see it as rejection. Pretend I just changed the status of our relationship to "it's complicated".
It really is sad to see you go. But the party's over, and now we have to clean things up.
It's not that peace is such a great idea. And certainly not with you. But sadly, it's probably the smart thing to do.
I know, peace is so booooring. No songs, no excitement, no explosions. We just feel like offering it today.
Do accept the offer. Stop by, have a chat, offer us gifts. Peace can really be diverting, you know.
I like you less and less. This is sort of a last-ditch offer to see if we can work things out.
So tell me what you think. It could be fun. Or not. I'm feeling sort of ambivalent about the whole thing.
Oh, you ought to say yes. "Open borders" is like "open house". A big party, and everyone's invited!
Enough already. If you want to trade, then trade. But you're no longer my favorite enemy.
You have some nice things. I have some nice things. We could trade them. Doesn't that make you feel special?
I just know you're going to love this! And if you don't, you're wrong, so get over it.
This doesn't mean we trust you. It only means that the Delegates have asked for a cease fire.
War is tiring, risky, and distracting. I think we've had enough of it for now.
I'm not convinced being at war with you is in anyone's best interest. Perhaps we were wrong about you.
I'm not convinced it's a good idea, but I'm offering to co-operate with you anyway.
Let's try this out. It may work, it may not.
Things are getting better and prospects are looking up. I say we move ahead together.
It's against my better judgment. But Delegates that I trust say we should co-operate more closely, so I'll make the proposal.
An alliance could be in both our interests. Maybe we should try it out.
As we move ahead in our mission to discover the Endless, we'd like to have you as an ally. That's how much we trust you.
It's getting worse, and there's no end in sight. We're going to have to clear the air the hard way.
Nobody likes it when it works out his way, but sometimes it just does. Endless preserve us.
It's too bad we have to do this, seeing how things were going. But I'm out of options right now, and this is what the Delegates want.
I don't like how things are going -- relations have started to slip. But maybe if you join up, we can fix that.
It's not clear, but there may be some advantages in bringing you into the fold. What do you say?
We like what we see and I like how things are going. What do you say you join our alliance?
It couldn't last. Things are going bad between us, and I don't want to risk the alliance on that.
It was a hard decision, but in the end I'm thinking it's better if you go. Endless preserve you.
I'm sorry to shock you like this, but after discussion with the Delegates we're afraid we have to ask you to go.
I'm not sure you're the type of people to offer peace to, but we generally find it's preferable to war.
All in all, peace seems like a good idea. What do you think?
The logical next step is peace, and the Delegates agree that you're a people we can trust.
We're ready to open our borders up in spite of your recent actions. Endless watch over us all…
If you tally up both sides, it comes out about even. I say we go ahead and risk open borders. You?
It's an act of trust, and of hope. We're willing to open our borders if you'll do the same.
We don't like how things have been evolving lately. But the Delegates still want to offer you this deal.
It's dark and solitary out here. A mutual exchange might be a good way to make life a little easier.
You're a trustworthy people, and we don't mind doing business with you.
The Chiefs don't like it, but I'll offer it anyway.
Maybe we've done enough mutual damage. What do you say?
We shouldn't be at each other's throats.
I'm not sure I trust you. View this as "co-operation, or else…"
I'm sure we could find something mutually beneficial. There's a lot of galaxy out there.
We have some solid ties between our two groups. Don't see why we shouldn't co-operate more closely.
If the Chiefs didn't tell me to do this, I wouldn't consider it. You got something to prove to me.
I think we could make this work. And I think we'd work out better as allies than not.
I won't pretend. We get along well with you guys, and an alliance could only help us both.
I'm hoping you didn't expect flowers.
Sometimes it happens. That's just how life is.
I'd rather not have to do it this way. But sometimes there's no choice.
You got something to prove here, understood? But I'll take a chance.
We could use some more good people here.
The Legion and the alliance would both be glad to see you join. How about it?
No hard feelings. It's just what the Legion wants.
It looks like it isn't working out. One of us has to go, and it won't be the Legion.
I got a bad feeling here. But a peace treaty still might make sense.
Could be a good idea. We figure we might as well try it out.
Listen to me. A peace treaty is the right things to do.
Okay, we'll try open borders. But the Legion isn't convinced you're pure as the snow on this.
Mutual benefit. Simplify travel and trade. Me and the Chiefs say it makes sense. You?
This here's a no-brainer. We trust each other, and it's gonna make our lives easier.
Take it or leave it. I'm not a big fan of yours right now.
I'm guessing it makes sense. We could do a deal, both walk away happy.
We'd be happy to trade with you guys. Let's see what we can work out.
Okay, I'm offering a cease fire. No, I don't like it, but I got out-voted.
We might as well do a cease fire, right? Lots of other things to do in life besides shoot at each other.
C'mon, stop it already. There's only so many useful resources we can blow up before we all look stupid.
Personally, I think "co-operate" has too many syllables for you to understand. But they still want to propose it.
What do you say? We work together, we both get something. You get brains, we get… hmmm…
C'mon c'mon it's a great idea. At least it is for you, and two of the three of us think it's good for us. Yeah, the other two.
I feel like an idiot proposing this, the way you've been acting. I'm really hoping there'll be some long-term benefits.
This is a good idea. Obviously, because we said so. Look, we're smart. Trust us.
Seriously this could be great. Think about it! Sophon science, Sophon technology, Sophon tourists…
War is really stupid. But you are so much stupider that we don't really have a choice.
Yeah, yeah. I know it's usually a bad idea. But this is how the numbers worked out, okay?
This is a lousy idea. You were finally starting to shape up! But too little, too late…
Outvoted again. And I annoyed them so much that they told me I had to make the offer. So here it is. Interested?
It could be smart to join our alliance. We won't know until we try it, but all the forecasts look pretty good.
Come on, join the alliance. It must be a good idea, because it came from the Sophons. Those are the only ideas we have.
Yes! Out! Go! You have no idea how good it feels to say that, seeing the way you have been acting.
The math works out pretty balanced. But I figure it's a better idea if you leave. Sorry.
You were doing better. Much better. But a Sophon's gotta do what a Sophon's gotta do. You're out!
Oooooh, they made me do this. I really don't like peace treaties with people who annoy me.
It's probably to our mutual benefit. And we calculated 'probably' to 30-plus decimal points.
C'mon, let's go. Make peace and shake hands, so then we can go do dangerous science together.
I'd rather keep them closed, seeing the way you have been acting. But statisticians say it's a good idea, and we like a well-crafted equation.
If we offer this, there's a pretty good chance it's to our benefit. No, we didn't calculate your benefit. Geez, show up for work!
What a great idea. I mean I've had great ideas before -- tons of them -- but this one is really great. Just sign here, okay?
Okay, you can have some stuff. I hear primitives like you really like things that are shiny.
What do you say to a couple of deals, a little trade? Pretty good idea, right?
Oh, this is a good one. We both get what we want, and more important, I get what I want. Perfect!

Benefits likely to outweigh costs and penalties. More detailed review of factors recommended.
Excellent probabilities of significant increase in numerous execution parameters for Calling. Recommended.
Potential benefits unacceptable. Recommendation: Reject proposal.
Departure from current alliance network probable. Relations trending negatively on latest analyses.
Secession observed to have positive and negative effects. Further study desired if possible.
Current proposition an outlier compared to previous models. Departure from alliance likely to negatively impact Calling.
Potential benefits unacceptable. Recommendation: Reject proposal.
Secession observed to have positive and negative effects. Further study desired if possible.
Current proposition an outlier compared to previous models. Departure from alliance likely to negatively impact Calling.
Long-term stability of pacific relations deemed unlikely. Negative response required.
Cessation of conflict desired, but risk/reward analysis remains negative.
Forecasts indicate advantages to Calling slightly outweigh inconveniences. Additional variables being considered.
Improvements to current Calling projects likely to be found across disciplines. Recommendation is positive.
Trust and/or stability of other party estimated at low to very low. Approval not recommended.
Analysis of partner proposition interesting, but not yet acceptable.
Joint risk and exposure possible; interesting variation on Prisoner's Dilemma. To be analyzed in further detail.
Improved transport and travel forecasts likely to improve current targets. Proposal has been recommended.
Potential benefits unacceptable. Recommendation: Reject proposal.
Not a preferred outcome. Positive response not recommended.
Profitable exchange possible along numerous axes. Investigate opportunity further.
Improved exchange likely to confer important efficiency gains. Positive response preferred.
We understand that you are busy fighting a war, so we'll make this simple: No.
A cease fire means exchanging the profits of conquest for the profits of trade. The balance is not yet in favor of commerce.
We do not fear military solutions to problems, though we do acknowledge the usefulness of diplomacy. We will consider it.
The fiscal advantages of war no longer apply to our situation; a change of status could well be considered.
We have studied your generous offer, and found that it doesn't meet some of our criteria -- such as common sense.
Co-operation should be profitable to all entities involved. Currently, your proposal is insufficient.
Improved commerce is generally to our advantage, though in this case it is not all that simple. This calls for deliberation.
We see you as a potentially profitable friend and neighbor; enhanced co-operation could be beneficial.
It is important to choose one's allies carefully, and that is why we are not choosing you.
An alliance is a major undertaking. Right now we don't see the potential profit negating the predicted risk.
Alliances, like marriages, depend on the trust and openness of the partners. We must consider this carefully.
We are willing to meet you at the altar. But be warned; we are neither cheap nor easy.
We will not say that we wanted this war, but we do say that we are not surprised to see it happen.
War is not always preferable, but occasionally necessary. Are you sure this is what you want?
We do not see war as always being profitable, but you will see that we do not fear to execute it.
Understand that this is likely to have a negative impact on trade and commerce. But if we must, we will.
We will not say that we wanted this war, but we do say that we are not surprised to see it happen.
We do not see war as always being profitable, but you will see that we do not fear to execute it.
Understand that this is likely to have a negative impact on trade and commerce. But if we must, we will.
Your current proposal is far below an acceptable threshold of profitability. As such, the Empire cannot accept it.
Joining your alliance is not, as far as we can see, fiscally interesting for the United Empire.
We have watched the creation and growth of this alliance. However, we had not considered membership and must review it carefully.
We could not help but notice the quality of your alliance, and are quite interested in helping you to exploit it.
Many relationships, whatever their qualities, do come to an end. And so it is with this one.
Departure from the alliance is not in our best interests, given your proposal.
Our relationship is difficult, but divorce may not be the answer. We will consider this.
We are not convinced that it is in our interest, or the interest of the alliance, that we secede from it.
Many relationships, whatever their qualities, do come to an end. And so it is with this one.
Our relationship is difficult, but divorce may not be the answer. We will consider this.
We are not convinced that it is in our interest, or the interest of the alliance, that we secede from it.
We don't see an offer of peace as being in our best interest, nor do we see you as a reliable partner.
We can consider a permanent treaty, but currently the conditions are not favorable enough.
Peace has its advantages, but also its inconveniences. We will mull over your proposal.
It is time to turn our factories and our people to other tasks. An end to this conflict would be desirable.
While we understand that you would like to have the freedom to travel within our borders, we would like it much less.
Travel within the Empire is possible, but the risks involved are not outweighed by the benefits you offer.
You show me yours and I'll show you mine, is it? This is a risky game, but one that we could both profit from.
From the Empire's point of view, increased travel and trade between our cultures can only be to the profit of both.
We have studied your generous offer, and found that it doesn't meet some of our criteria -- such as common sense.
Co-operation should be profitable to all entities involved. Currently, your proposal is insufficient.
Improved commerce is generally to our advantage, though in this case it is not all that simple. This calls for deliberation.
From the Empire's point of view, increased trade between our cultures can only be to the profit of both.
The research you were doing has been successfully completed.

THE ENEMY HERO HAS BEEN INJURED
