Welcome to a new game of Endless Space. This Tutorial will guide you through a series of screens explaining the game mechanics.
If you disable the Tutorial with the button below, you can re-activate it in the game options. You can restart a new game to make sure you have not missed any Tutorial information.
Press OK to proceed.
This screen is an overview of the game galaxy.
Your home system is centered on the screen. Zoom in/out using the mouse wheel. Press the left mouse button and drag to move the view.
The control banner at the top of the screen gives you access to the different departments of your empire. Hovering over these icons displays status information.

You conquer the galaxy by colonizing Star Systems. Each Star System holds up to 6 diverse planets. The dots over the star name indicate the number and type of planets: Blue are already colonized, white planets are colonizable, red planets cannot be colonized yet.
Stars are connected by cosmic strings, natural links which allow fast travel. Other, more advanced means of travelling can be unlocked later.
The flag above a star system informs that a unique exploration event awaits the very first player to travel this far.
When an important event occurs, usually at the beginning of the turn, an icon appears. Clicking on the icon will open a detailed panel, which you can either minimize or dismiss (like the icon).
The auto-cycle button allows you to review all your fleets that remain around planets, waiting for your orders.
All planned moves of your fleets can be executed automatically thanks to the forced-move button.
Once you have completed all of your actions for the turn, press the end-turn button in the lower right corner to advance constructions and research as well as move ships and fleets.
This screen shows a Star System's status and allows you to manage its production.
The Star System name is displayed here; click on it to change it if you wish.
A Star System produces four basic outputs: Food, Industry, Dust, and Science. Together, they are known as FIDS.
A Star System's population increases when there is sufficient food output. The more population units the planet has, the more FIDS it will generate.
The Star System's Approval represents how happy the people are in this system. This will affect the FIDS output.

Your Star System contains up to 6 planets of various types. You start with one colonized planet, and may need more advanced technology to colonize new planet types. The base FIDS production of each planet is multiplied by its current population, then added to the system's FIDS.
When you control more than one planet in a system, you can drag and drop population units between them to optimize the FIDS output.
In the Development panel you can add Star System Improvements or ships to the production queue.

Once a construction has been selected, it appears in the Star System production queue. Next to it you can see the number of turns required to complete it. If you hover over the 'Dust' symbol you will see the cost required to complete the construction in 1 turn. Click the symbol if you wish to do this. You can drag and drop items to change their order in the queue.
When a spaceship is built, it is stored in the Star System's hangar. The ship will remain in the hangar until you assemble it into a fleet.
Some Star System Improvements have an upkeep cost. They can be scrapped if your empire's treasury runs low.
You can assign a Hero to govern a Star System. Depending on their specializations, the Hero can provide bonuses in things like production output, defense, etc.

If Luxury or Strategic Resources are present, they become available throughout your empire. These resources allow advanced constructions, and can be traded with friendly empires. If an enemy fleet is in orbit, that Star System is in a Blockade. It can no longer share resources with your or any other empire.

When you are at Peace with at least one empire, Trade Routes are automatically created. They provide bonuses in Dust and Science. A Star System under Blockade (with an enemy fleet present) loses all its Trade routes.
Clicking on a planet provides details of the planet. From here you can select advanced planetary options.
Planet types vary in terms of FIDS outputs.

A planet may hold an Anomaly, which can alter (for better or worse) its FIDS and other values. It may also hold a Wonder, a Natural or an Endless one, which gives a boost to the planet or the whole system.To activate an Endless Wonder, the structure must be rebuilt first.
A planet may also hold a Luxury or Strategic Resource, which usually requires research of a specific technology to receive those bonuses.

The planet population is defined by maximum (white) and a current (blue) values. The current value represents the active population, which is multiplied by the base FIDS output of the planet to determine its contribution to the system FIDS.
Once you have colonized a Star System from a ship, you can colonize other planets inside that system from the Planet View (provided you have discovered the right technology for that planet type).
There are many development options for a planet once it has been colonized.

Each planet can have one type of exploitation, which specializes it to producing one of the FIDS. You can only have one exploitation at a time on a planet, but you can replace it with a different one.
Some negative Anomalies can be countered by Anomaly Reduction options, when the proper technology has been discovered.
When unlocked through research, Terraforming options allow you to change one planet type to another.
A planet may have a moon. Once you have done a Moon Survey, the moon may reveal a hidden temple. These temples can provide critical advantages to the Star System, and even to your Empire.
Colonization, exploitations, anomaly reductions, terraformations and moon surveys are all stacked in the system construction queue, which will implement them one at a time.
This panel is for managing fleets and ships in Galaxy View.
The spaceship symbol next to your home planet represents one or more fleets. When you click on this symbol, a fleet control panel appears, and the fleet (or fleets) are selected.
In the fleet list half of the panel (left), you can see the details of each fleet.
Selecting an individual fleet displays the list of ships in that fleet on the right. You can drag and drop ships from fleet to fleet.

Once a fleet is selected, order it to move by right-clicking on a destination star (connected by a string). The fleet will start moving, but may take more than one turn to arrive at its destination. Technology advances will speed up this movement.

The Fleet Control panel also has some special actions, which will blink when available. For example, when a fleet containing a colony ship orbits a Star System, you can press the blinking Colonize button to settle one of the planets in that Star System.
This screen gives you an overview of your empire. You can also perform actions on your Star Systems from here.
This is your empire's Dust treasury, as well as the projected income / loss for the next turn.

This is your empire's Approval rating. The more content your citizens are, the more they will produce and research, and the faster your population will grow. Empire Approval is the average of each Star System's Approval, weighted by population.
Increasing your Tax rate will also increase your Dust production, but will reduce your Approval. Reducing the Tax rate will have the opposite effect.
The list of Star Systems can be sorted in different ways by clicking on the header tab for each column.
Clicking on the appropriate cell allows you to manage a planet's population, assign heroes, change the production queue, and manage the ships in the hangar.
You can also ask the AI to take over a system's management. Select the area you want the AI to focus on from the drop down list.
This is a quick overview of all the bonus / penalty factors that currently affect your empire.
This is the list of all the effects generated by your Trade Routes.

This screen allows you to research new technologies to improve your empire. The technologies are divided into four main categories. The farther away from the center, the more advanced the technology is.
"Exploration and Expansion" allows you to navigate faster and farther, unlock new spaceship hulls, and colonize or improve new planet types.
"Applied Sciences" are for improving your empire's economy and sciences, as well as discovering Strategic Resources.
"Diplomacy and Trade" helps you in agriculture, diplomacy, and finance, and also helps you manage your citizens.
"Galactic Warfare" unlocks new combat modules to outfit your ships, and makes ships more efficient in combat.

When you click on a technology, you select it and its associated modules for research. Technologies are researched one at a time, and research advances to the next queued technology when one is complete.
You can consult your research rate and queued technologies in this panel.
You can use the mouse wheel or scale control to zoom in or out.
When you zoom in all the way, you can see the details of each research option.
Each technology has a research cost (in Science points) that is directly converted into the number of turns it takes to research.
When technology research is completed (blue), it unlocks improvements of various kinds: Star System improvements, new ship hulls, planetary exploitations... Basically, everything in the game.
Technologies are connected by dependencies. To research a technology, you must have discovered at least one technology connected to it (closer to the center of the wheel).
The technology currently being researched is surrounded by a green wave pattern. Other technologies in the research queue are also colored in green.
Some technologies are specific to the empire you play; those have an orange icon.
If you are looking for a specific technology or module/improvement, simply type a keyword in the Quick Find box and hit return. You can then cycle through the matching elements.
You can consult your military status on this view -- both active fleets and available Ship Designs.
Fleets are presented in rows that show detailed information on the fleet stats as well as its location. Double-clicking on a fleet will open and center the Galaxy View on this fleet's location.

When you select a single fleet by clicking it, the ships contained in this fleet are displayed in the area below. You can drag and drop ships between fleets if the fleets are located in the same Star System.
Selecting fleets and ships will open up options for managing them.
If you hold “Ctrl” while selecting fleets, you can select multiple fleets. Fleets can be merged if they orbit the same Star System.
If you disband a fleet, for instance to reduce your empire upkeep, its ships will be returned to the hangar if the fleet orbits one of your Star Systems. Otherwise, the ships are scrapped.
Use the Retrofit button to upgrade Ships or entire fleets to the latest revision of their Ship Design. This will cost you some Dust.

Available Ship Designs shows the current Ship Designs created for your empire. A Ship Design is a template which can be used to produce ships in your Star Systems. Ship designs can be modified and evolved through “revisions”, as you research new ship modules or change your strategies.

You can create new Ship Designs anytime, and should do so when a new ship class becomes available. Ship designs can be removed, but this will prevent you from retrofitting any older ships in your fleets that have that design.
When you select a Ship Design or a ship within a fleet, you will see detailed information on its design.
The Ship Design Details panel displays various statistics for a Ship Design, as well as the types and numbers of ship modules outfitted to that ship.
The Military Power (MP) is a compound representation of a ship's combat strength, combining offense and defense.
Modules are organized in categories, with the total weight and effect (usually MP) summarized.
Click the Modify button to edit a Ship Design.
The Ship Design view is used to create new Ship Designs or modify existing ones. Basically, a Ship Design is the combination of a ship class (or hull) and a list of ship modules.

When you create a new Ship Design, you select a ship class here. Ship classes vary in tonnage and also offer special bonuses to certain module types. The greater the tonnage, the more Industry points the ship will cost to build.
If this is a new Ship Design, you must give it a name of your choosing.
The tonnage is an absolute limit to how many ship modules you can build into a ship. Some technologies allow you increase the ship tonnage capacity through miniaturization.
As you progress in the game, you will discover new modules to install in your ships. Use these tabs to switch between the families of modules: Weapon, Defense, and Support.
To install a module on a ship, simply click on the module in the “Available Modules” area.

Modules will be disabled (gray) if their weight exceeds the remaining tonnage capacity or, as in this case, if the module requires access to a Strategic Resource. You can still create a Ship Design with these modules, but you must have access to the Strategic Resource via colonization or Trade to build ships based on that Ship Design.
The “Selected Modules” area summarizes the modules currently selected for the Ship Design. Simply click on a module to remove it from the Ship Design and free up some hull space.
You can click the auto-upgrade button to automatically fill up the ship with modules.
Once you are finished, click the Create/Apply button.

The Academy is where you hire or manage Heroes, powerful characters who can greatly improve the efficiency of your Star Systems and fleets. The Academy is separated into two parts: the management of active Heroes, and the recruitment of new Heroes.

When you click on the lower part, you switch the top and bottom halves of the View. Whenever you enter the screen it is set to Hero management on top (assign or re-assign Heroes to fleets and systems, inspect their abilities) and Hero recruitment on bottom (a list of available Heroes, if any).

When one of the two lists is selected, its available actions appear as you select each Hero. These actions will depend on the list (manage or recruit) and the situation of the hero (not hired, idle, injured, assigned to a fleet, etc.).

When you start the game, some Heroes are available for hire. More will come after a number of turns. To hire a Hero, select the recruit list, select the Hero, and click the Hire button. This will deduct the hiring cost from your treasury.

Once a Hero is hired, his/her upkeep cost will be subtracted from your empire treasury each turn. If you are having financial problems you can Expel a hero to save Dust, but he will leave your empire permanently.

The standard activity for an active hero is to manage a fleet or a Star System, which you perform by clicking on the Assign buttons in the manage list. The game also offers many shortcuts to assign heroes directly from the Star System View or Fleet View interfaces.
If you want to know more about a Hero, you can click the Inspect button to check out their information and abilities.
The Hero inspection panel displays critical information about a Hero, and also allows you to select new abilities as your Hero progresses in skill.
A Hero's overall power is defined by their level, which is the same for both classes.
Each Hero has two classes (out of 5 possible) which determine their ability to perform certain missions. Some Heroes will be more adapted to governing Star Systems, others to commanding fleets.
The upkeep cost of the Hero needs to be paid each turn by your empire, and increases as the Hero gains levels.
The Hero attributes determine the bonus they bring to a Star System or fleet. These attributes can be increased by selecting certain abilities when the Hero gains a level.
When a Hero has gained enough experience governing a Star System or commanding a fleet, they gain a new level and can unlock a new ability.
As long as you have ability points left, you can select an ability to acquire it for the Hero.
This area summarizes all the bonuses provided by the Hero.
The Diplomacy View shows your diplomatic status with other empires, and lets you contact them to make (or break) agreements.

When you open this view, you as the emperor are in the center, represented by a holographic figure. Around you are pedestals for the leaders of the other empires in the game. These will be empty until you make contact with those empires.
Your status with other empires is shown by the lines radiating from your image. The color and symbols of those lines represent the current diplomatic situation: War, Cold War, Peace, or Alliance.
The attitudes towards the centered empire are displayed through emotional icons. It gives a quick overview of the relationship status between empires in addition to the line type.
You can click on another emperor to center them in the view and see their relations with other empires.
When an empire is selected, you can click the Inspection icon to show information about this empire (including your own).
Once an empire is selected, you can click the Contact icon to open negotiations with this empire.

Once you have contacted an empire, the diplomatic negotiations panel opens to allow you to prepare the terms of the deal you want to offer. Your empire is represented on the left part of the screen, the other empire on the right.
A deal is an exchange of diplomatic terms. The other empire must agree to the deal for it to become active, unless you are declaring War -- they get no choice on that.
You can switch between different categories of terms with these tabs: Treaties to change your status or to exchange Dust, technologies, or Star Systems.
Select items from the list that appears in order to determine your offer.
Select terms or items from the contacted empire to explain what you want to request in return for what you are offering.
Once you are ready, you can click the “Offer” button to send your proposal to the contacted empire. Note: They will not necessarily accept it.
In parallel with the written reaction of the contacted empire, the deal balance gauge lets you know how likely it is that the deal will succeed, to make sure you do not offer too much or too little.

The different resources are displayed for both empire. Numbers on the left are the amount at disposal for an offer and numbers on the right are what the empire receives in total (through current deals for instance).
Use these buttons to see your previous deals with this empire (or all empires).

This panel gives information on an empire, and lists the deals you have signed with it. When you select your own empire, you will see your own empire information and all the deals signed with other empires.
The current status is shown here, as well as this empire's attitude towards you. If they like you, it will be easier to strike deals or even form a long term alliance.
The score is a good indication of how well this empire is doing. You can also check the score by hovering on the galaxy icon of the Galaxy View banner.
This area lists all the accumulated faction traits of this empire. This can tell you how dangerous this empire might be, or what its preferred path to victory is.
This part summarizes the deals currently in progress with the empire.
You can terminate a deal by clicking this button.
However, killing a deal will incur an attitude penalty with the other empire. This penalty gradually decreases as turns pass.
When an optional battle is possible at the arrival around a system, the Fleet Attack icon starts blinking.

Clicking this icon opens the Encounter Panel, which gives you critical information before the battle. This panel opens automatically if the enemy attacks you. Your forces are shown on the left, the enemy's forces on the right.
The strength of each fleet is represented by its health and military power, which is the sum of all ships of the fleet.
You can see the order of battle of the ships participating in the battle, and hover your cursor to check their stats.
The balance of power gauge represents your chances of winning the battle. It compares the product of current health percentage by military power for you and your opponent.
If you feel secure enough to win the battle you can play it in Auto mode; otherwise, select the Manual option to visualize and direct the encounter.
The Battle View opens when one of your fleets confronts the enemy in a Star System. This view also allows you to choose Battle Actions to increase your chances of winning the engagement.
The battle is subdivided into phases: A prologue, three combat phases, and an epilogue phase.
The three combat phases are also shown in your Fleet Command interface.
During the long range phase, missiles are more effective.
During the medium range phase, beams are more effective.
During the melee phase, kinetic weapons are more effective.
You can select a Battle Action for each combat phase.
The list of ships into the current fleet is shown with a real-time state update.
The battle can end in a victory, defeat, or even a draw if both fleets survive. Survivors can resume the fight on the next turn.
When you click on the Battle Action icon for each combat phase, the Battle Action choice panel appears. Simply click on a card to select it.
The Battle Actions are presented as cards. Each one has a color that corresponds to their action "family." The family is also displayed on top of the card.
Each card can counter another family of cards, resulting in an improved effect for the action. The countered family is displayed at the bottom of the card.
Some Battle Action cards are free to use, requiring 0 Dust to activate. Those are technological actions, unlocked through scientific research.

Some action cards require Dust to activate, but their effect is quasi magical in nature, due to the uncanny ability of Heroes to create powerful effects by manipulating Dust. Those actions are unlocked by your Heroes as they gain levels, and they must be an admiral in the battling fleet for their actions to be available.
When you do not have enough Dust to activate an action, it is grayed out and the cost is displayed in red.
The Battle Action cards list the base and improved effects of the action. You can check your available Battle Actions at any time via the Fleet Control panel.
Once a battle is resolved, you can check the Battle Report in the Encounter Panel.
The health and Military Power of remaining ships are updated.
Destroyed and surviving ships are displayed for each side.
Global statistics summarize your ship losses and show how much XP a Hero has earned.
If a Hero was injured, they are returned to your Academy, waiting to be healed.
The second column displays how much damage you inflicted on the enemy as well as the efficiency percentage (how much damage passed through the enemy defenses) for each of your active weapon types.

The last column is the opposite, showing how much damage the enemy inflicted on you, and how efficient your defenses were against incoming enemy weapons. Analyzing offensive and defensive stats will allow you to optimize your ship designs to better defeat your enemies.
You will be able to colonize other Star Systems soon after you start playing the game.
Newly colonized Star Systems start as Outposts, gradually evolving into full-fledged Colonies.
Colonies generate a border around them, which defines your empire's frontiers. This territory expands as the system grows.
Spaceships have a detection range, which reveals nearby enemy ships.
When you meet with new empires you share a status of Cold War. That is unchanged unless you declare war or are able to negotiate peace.
When in Cold War, all ships can engage in battle outside of their empire territory.
Outposts control no territory until they become full Colonies. They can be invaded by enemy forces without a declaration of war as they are not yet part of your empire territory.
They're not so united, the planets of this "United Empire. "
It's more a gaggle of unruly imperial corporations run by insolent dukes.
But their armies are strong, their economy is efficient,
… and their ships are powerful. I fear that they may be the ones
… who will finally unite -- or dominate -- the galaxy.
They'll turn it into a shrine to the gods of commerce;
… a profane church with Emperor Maximilian Zelevas as its high priest.
The normal attitude toward the Cravers is fear.
Half-insect, half-machine, their only desire is to expand
… and conquer and devour to feed their hives.
They have little understanding of pain or fear or defeat.
For the Endless built them that way; a living weapon.
And if they do not expand, they will consume themselves.
And their hive leader would much prefer to consume you.
They are the Horatio, created from cloning technology of the Endless.
He... they... it is difficult to differentiate.
Spreading themselves across their home system,
Horatio wished to fill it with subjects as beautiful
…. as the most beautiful thing in the universe.
Now his goal is to make the entire galaxy beautiful as well.
And he doesn't really care if the galaxy agrees.
What we call barbaric ritual, the Hissho call noble tradition.
What we call brutal, they call just.
What we call slaughter, they call glory.
The Hissho have an obsession with blood;
whether offering their own or sacrificing an enemy.
And whether they rule the galaxy and demand tribute from lesser nations,
…or die in the effort to do so, they will consider their crusade successful.
For their traditions demand either your blood, or theirs.
Some say that victory is worth any cost,
... but only the Sophons would say that about knowledge.
They learn from a young age that the universe is a great puzzle,
…and are obsessive about uncovering its secrets.
Do not look for them at the forefront of battle, for that is not their way.
For the Sophons, the only place to take life-endangering risks
Pedantic, argumentative, and arrogant… but curious, always curious.
Have you stood before the colossal remnants of an ancient civilization?
Then you may understand how the Pilgrims regard the Endless.
Awe, respect, fear... and obsessive curiosity.
Something in those ruins touched a deeper chord than science can,
… and as well as explorers and scientists they are now tattooed mystics.
They cross the stars, to find more systems, more ruins.
To find Tor, homeworld of the Endless.
And their charismatic and passionate leader
The oldest nation that we know of,
the Amoeba strive to live in harmony.
…and even, in space, with their ships.
They have been watching and listening to the stars for ages,
… hearing the words of the cosmos itself.
For the belief of the Amoeba is to represent all life,
… and see that it lives in harmony everywhere in the galaxy.
They were dropped, ages ago, onto a lifeless rock;
...under orders from the Endless they turned it into a paradise.
For one day, they are sure, the Endless will return,
… and the entire galaxy must be pacified for them.
The Sowers will permit no living thing
